title: Blockhead
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
inscription: Comic text by Koppi Dōjin; {Meiji nijūshichinen jūnigatsu}
text: This woodblock series, created during the Sino-Japanese War (1894-95), reveals Kiyochika's political views and his fierce patriotism. To express his contempt for the Chinese and his support for the Japanese troops, Kiyochika collaborated with the writer Koppi Døjin. Here, the writer's comic text appears in a box in the upper part of the print. The man seated behind the red table represents the Chinese army at the Lushun Fortress, a historical stronghold in North China that was once believed to be impregnable. Calling it "blockhead," the writer and the artist applaud Japan's unexpectedly easy victory in taking Lushun.
portfolio: From Long Live Japan: One Hundred victories, One Hundred Laughs
creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
artist: Artist: Kobayashi Kiyochika; Publisher: Daikokuya Heikichi
